The Null Object Pattern

Source: vignettes/patterns/NullObject.Rmd
NullObject.Rmd

Caution: NullObject is designed for demonstration purposes. Instead of directly using the design pattern as it appears in the package, you’d have to adjust the source code to the problem you are trying to solve.

Null Object …

How It Works

When to Use It

  • In situations when a subroutine is likely to fail, such as loss of Internet or database connectivity. Instead of prompting a run-time error, you could return the Null Object as part of a gracefully failing strategy. A common strategy employs tryCatch that returns the Null Object in case of an error:
set.seed(1814)

# Adult value object constructor
Adult <- function(age = NA_integer_){
  if(isTRUE(age < 18)) stop("Can not instantiate minors") 
  tibble::tibble(age = age) %>% tidyr::drop_na(age)
}

# A Non-Null Adult object is
print(Adult(age = 42))
#> # A tibble: 1 x 1
#>     age
#>   <dbl>
#> 1    42
# The Null Adult object is
print(Adult())
#> # A tibble: 0 x 1
#> # … with 1 variable: age <int>

# Subroutine with gracefully failing strategy
# Notice: Whether the subroutine fails or succeeds, it returns a tibble with 
# the same structure.
adult <- tryCatch(
  # Try instantiating an Adult value object
  Adult(age = sample(1:120)), 
  # If there is an error, return the Null Adult object
  error = function(e) return(Adult()) 
)
  • In unit-tests

Example: Null ggplot2

geom_null <- function(...){
  ggplot2::ggplot() + ggplot2::geom_blank() + ggplot2::theme_void()
}

Example: Null Value Object

Person <- function(given = NA_character_, family = NA_character_){
  tibble::tibble(given = given, family = family) %>% tidyr::drop_na(given)
}

# Instantiating a person with a `given` name, returns a non-null person object
print(Person("Madonna"))
#> # A tibble: 1 x 2
#>   given   family
#>   <chr>   <chr> 
#> 1 Madonna <NA>

# Instantiating a person without a `given` name, returns the null person object
print(Person())
#> # A tibble: 0 x 2
#> # … with 2 variables: given <chr>, family <chr>
